title: Effect of mutation on protein function

content.description: Beta thalassemia is a disorder caused by mutations in the <math alttext="H B B" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>H</mi> <mi>B</mi> <mi>B</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> gene. Examination of the <math alttext="H B B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HBB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in an individual with beta thalassemia shows that the protein is missing many amino acids at its carboxyl terminus.
content.question: Which of the following is the most likely explanation for how a mutation in the <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> could result in the loss of the carboxyl terminus of the <math alttext="H B B" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>HBB</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> protein?

choices.label: The mutation keeps the <math alttext="H B B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene wrapped tightly around histones, preventing transcription of the gene.
The mutation changes the promoter sequence of the gene such that different transcription factors initiate transcription of the gene.

The mutation changes a codon in the coding region of the <math alttext="H B B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> transcript to a stop codon such that translation terminates earlier than it should.
The mutation results in hydrogen bonds between adjacent amino acids instead of covalent bonds, resulting in the production of an unstable protein.

content.answer: The mutation changes a codon in the coding region of the <math alttext="H B B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> transcript to a stop codon such that translation terminates earlier than it should.
